snippet: In an extraordinary intelligence coup, the would-be suicide bomber dispatched by the Al Qaeda branch in Yemen last month infiltrated the terrorist group and volunteered for the mission, officials said.
abstract: American and foreign officials reveal that the would-be suicide bomber dispatched by Al Qaeda in the Arab Peninsula to blow up a United States-bound airliner was actually a Saudi intelligence agent who infiltrated the terrorist group and volunteered for the mission; in an intelligence coup, the Saudi spy turned over both the bomb and key data on the terrorist group; officials say that the agent operated in Yemen with the full knowledge of the Central Intelligence Agency, but not under its direct supervision. (M)

byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE and ERIC SCHMITT; Robert F. Worth and Michael S. Schmidt contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The suicide bomber dispatched by the Yemen branch of Al Qaeda last month to blow up a United States-bound airliner was actually an intelligence agent for Saudi Arabia who infiltrated the terrorist group and volunteered for the mission, American and foreign officials said Tuesday. In an extraordinary intelligence coup, the double agent left Yemen last month, traveling by way of the United Arab Emirates, and delivered both the innovative bomb designed for his aviation attack and inside information on the group's leaders, locations, methods and plans to the Central Intelligence Agency, Saudi intelligence and allied foreign intelligence agencies.

headline.main: Airline Plotter A Double Agent, U.S. Officials Say

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AL QAEDA IN THE ARABIAN PENINSULA
